comment: 1:19:27 this should be “swap e and e’ in T*”

The proof of the last theorem is not complete.  It says it exists an edge in E-S, it didn’t say that the algo must select the edge.  However, this part is implicitly proofed as within parts of the proof for last Lemma, that the algo chosen one can only comes from some MST.  It would be better to proof the last Lemma first (or to improve the Lemma definition to make it not only “exist”, but also IS the chosen one) , then the theorem proof would come more naturally.

Admitted I truly missed the experience of interacting with prof and other fellow classmates in a class room setting.  But between that and the option of breaking this lecture into 10 minutes slices that I can take while juggling among job, kids and learning? I will take the latter.  Thank you MIT for innovating a new system for maximizing human intelligence by including all of us who cannot afford to sit in the MIT classroom (financially or/and also from a time perspective).

Can anyone explain why theorem 2 requires the first point? Why do the intermediate steps matter when the theorem only requires the final step of the algorithm to be true, which is shown by the second point?

To be honest, I have found that I can understand the content of this course, but it is very hard to keep focusing on his lecture. Maybe English is not his native language, but his voice can not carry confidence.

To complete the proof at 30:05 do we not also need one more small lemma to justify that there was indeed a leaf to remove from the tree? The proof relied on removing a vertex which is a leaf. So I was thinking we need the lemma: all trees have at least one leaf.

23:26, there is also a way to prove this by proving two well-known results (and hence the lemma is just a corollary). 1. If a graph G is connected then |E| >= |V| - 1. 2. A graph G has a cycle if and only if |E| >= |V|. Both are proved by induction.

I think all the 'important' parts of the proof are in the lemma (on the left board) that says the algorithm has chosen some edges all are in a real MST.  The theorem at 1:00:00 only says the algorithm chooses any edge, so the algorithm always chooses 1 edge until n-1 edges are reached. After every chosen edge in any step the lemma says it was the right choice

Not necessary, you can say that P(n) is true. Add another vertex, this vertex can be connected to the tree by any number of edges. But if we use more than one edge the resulting graph will be circular(because n vertex graph was connected and connecting any two vertices with a third vertex leads to a cycle) thus the number of edges increases from n-1 to n.

If there are two vertices in a walk that are exactly the same, in the set they will be at a different index. If i were to be equal to J then in every walk that holds true, because in every walk every single vertex/node is the same as itself. If i is not the same as j then that means the two vertices are the same, but not their index in the set representing the walk.

nope. He actually made a reference to another theorem: one that says "there is a spanning tree for each connected graph". He used well-ordering principle on this statement and ended up with: "There exists MST for each connected graph".  That was essential to prove base case (empty set is a part of MST in our graph), which is obviously correct only if such MST actually exists in the graph. But yes, it was a bit confusing, since he said something like "according to this theorem", though it was not "this", but "one before this" thm.
